SpNote.note:
Choose the type of UFTI MSB you would like to make, copy it to your Science Program and then edit the values you need to change. Note that in all cases we have not included the required standard stars (for obvious reasons); these will have to be put in place manually.
There is no need to include an array_tests observation; this is available on an OMP query tool menu.
9 point or 5-point jitter patterns are available with standard offsets of 10 or 20 arcsecs. (Edit for non-standard offsets.)
Quadrant-jitter patterns for deep imaging are available.
Sky-and-jitter sequences are available for accurate photometry of faint sources.
5x5 and 3x3 mosaics for an extended source are available.
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.
SpNote.title: Contents and how to use them

This sequence is an example of how to do generic n-colour photometry efficiently in a single observation.
Although this is for JHK, you can change the filters to do any set. Note that at the moment only the jitter_self_flat_ncolour data reduction recipe is available, for historical reasons. Others will be made colour generic soon.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below sets to the J filter as a base configuration.
The sequence then takes darks with exposure times appropriate to each filter that will be used.
The UFTI filters and exposure times for each filter are then "iterated" (cycled through) in the sequence below.
The UFTI component below has exposures set for a 11-12 mag star. Change these as appropriate for your source.
SpNote.title: UFTI setup information

SpNote.note:
The data-reduction recipe specified below uses the most complete data-reduction recipe.
This recipe does self flat reduction for each colour. If you do each colour more than once then the data will be co-added for each.
Separate reduced files are generated for each colour.
The algorithm is identical to JITTER_SELF_FLAT.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the dark exposure time in the UFTI configuration above remember to change it here too.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Three darks are done here - one for each filter that will follow. Set the exposure times and co-adds to match those which you will do on the source in each band.
SpNote.title: set dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the 5-point jitter pattern more than once for each filter on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one 5-point jitter

SpNote.note: The UFTI iteration component below changes the filter, starting with J. No exposure time is entered for J because it is already set in the general UFTI setup above. The filter and exposure time are then changed for H and then again for K.
SpNote.title: UFTI filter iteration

SpNote.note:
The non-square pattern of offsets in the jitter below avoids re-inforcement of poor row/column.
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

This sequence is an example of how to do generic n-colour imaging in a single observation. The same sequence of JHK jitter patterns is repeated (the UFTI iterator is nested inside the Repeat iterator); thus, although this almost guarantees equal depth in each final mosaic, it involves more filter changes than the "Multi-colour (efficient)" sequence.
Although this is for JHK, you can change the filters to do any set. Note that at the moment only the JITTER_SELF_FLAT_NCOLOUR data-reduction recipe is available, for historical reasons. Others will be made colour generic soon.

Separate reduced files are generated for each colour.

SpNote.note:

SpNote.note: The UFTI iteration component below changes the filter, starting with J. The filter and exposure time are then changed for H and then again for K.

Although this is for JHK, you can change the filters to do any set. Note that at the moment only the JITTER_SELF_FLAT_NCOLOUR data-reduction recipe is available, for historical reasons. Others will be made colour generic soon.

5-point jitter offsets (repeated) on a bright point source. It is assumed that the background signal in the short-exposure images is insufficient to construct a good flat field. This sequence therefore requires a pre-observed flat field (use "make_skyflats").
For point sources, to cut down on overheads, use the UFTI sub-array and smaller jitter-steps.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the K filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The UFTI component below uses a 5-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "UFTI" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and the recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note:
If you want to do aperture photometry change the Recipe to BRIGHT_POINT_SOURCE_APHOT.
NOTE: A separate flat must have been acquired and filed in the same filter (use "make_skyflats"); the recipe also requires a dark with the same integration time.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the dark exposure time in the UFTI configuration above remember to change it here too.
N.B.:The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure time matches that in your UFTI setting above.
SpNote.title: set dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the 5-point jitter pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one 5-point jitter

SpNote.note:
The non-square pattern of offsets in the jitter below avoids re-inforcement of poor row/column.
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit the offset values.
Note, the 85" offsets should yield a 4.3' x 4.3' mosaic with no gaps between the frames (though almost no overlap either). The moderate ~7" overlap between frames should allow the DR to compare and balance the sky background in adjacent frames.
Note also that the guide star should be at least 100" from the edge of the guide-star field-of-view.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UFTI component then change the exposure time here to match it.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time. Use the reset-to-default button to set the exposure time to match your object exposure time above.

SpNote.title: how to do more than one quadrant jitter

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
Quadrant jitters move the source into each quadrant of the array. The flat field is generated for each quadrant by using the data from the frames for which the source was not in that quadrant. This works well for small extended sources.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: For convenience this final offset ensures the telescope moves back to 0,0 after all the observations have completed.
SpNote.title: final offset

SpNote.note:
CHOP_SKY_JITTER is suitable for extended sources that fill almost the whole array (so that sky frames or a flat field cannot be obtained from the on-source images). A median flat is constructed from ten "sky" observations, that are obtained after each object frame.
Recipe assumes that observations begin and end on sky.
N.B. Dark exposure also required.
If your observations are short, you may wish to substitute CHOP_SKY_JITTER_BASIC, which uses a no-frills algorithm.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UFTI configuration then remember to change it for the dark too.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.

SpNote.title: how to do more than one 9-point jitters

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region, which is defaulted to approximately 100 arcseconds east of the target.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the K filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The UFTI component below uses a 40-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "UFTI" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and the recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe used assumes that a flat field has already been created. It will not work unless you have done this. Use the observation "make sky flats" to do this.

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UFTI Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

Exec for making a map of a large source, < 2 arcmin. Images are taken in strips with semi-random ordering of positions in the strip and of the strip to minimise systematic errors due to sky fluctuations. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 150 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un guided"
It starts with sky then the "middle" frame.
For larger targets see also "extended_5x5".
If speed is an issue, select the simplest form of the recipe, namely EXTENDED_3x3_BASIC.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:

SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region(s), which default to approximately 210 arcseconds north-west and south-east of the target. If there is any doubt concerning the uniformity of the sky, it is better to restrict yourself to one sky region, so that changes in sky level can be measured, and not be attributed to a sky offset between regions. See the IRCAM3 equivalent of this observation for a template.
The target offsets are displaced to give 50% overlap; larger offsets resulting in less than 50% overlap may result in striping in the final mosaic due to different noise levels in the overlap regions.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.

Take three 5-second darks, so that the first one can be thrown away

SpNote.note:
Simply takes five short darks to flush the array of any residual bias structure or latency that may be left over from observing in twilight or from observing a last (bright) standard.
Also ensures that the blank is in place at the end of the night.
Use the QUICK_LOOK data-reduction recipe.
Take five 4-second darks.

To take 3 short dark exposures (full array) to "flush" the array of any latent images.
Note: These frames WILL be stored to disk.

SpNote.note:
This library contains basic CGS4 MSBs, for all four standard observing methods.
Flats and arcs are all flagged as optional
Standard stars are all flagged as optional.
Observer notes are included, which should be filled in to inform the observer at the telescope of any special requirements.
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.
SpNote.title: Contents and how to use them

The default for observing large extended objects.
If your target is only marginally extended, you should consider using the point source sequence. You should discuss this with your support scientist.
If your target is moderately (i.e. a few tens of arcsecs) extended, consider nodding along the slit with a suitably large nod distance. You should discuss this with your support scientist.

SpNote.note:
This is only for use when: a) the sky background is stable, b) your target is extended, and c) you cannot afford to spend 50% of your time observing blank sky;
i.e. faint, extended, echelle targets.
The sequence is that you start with a SKY frame, and then take several OBJECT frames. The DR will subtract the SKY from each of the following OBJECT frames. You can repeat this as many times as you like.
You can change the sky offset to your own patch of blank sky.
SpNote.title: Extended source with infrequent nod to blank sky

SpNote.note: These are *not* MSBs; they are straightforward Observations. all may be selected from the ukirtqt menu and thus do not have to be included in your MSBs.
SpNote.title: Utility sequences
Array Tests
SpNote.note: This is the array checkout proceedure. It should be run at the start of each night and if you suspect array problems. Do not alter this observation. The DR pipeline will tell you the readnoise and dark current on reducing this.

SpNote.title: End of Night
SpNote.note: Simply sets to a DARK configuration which is the best place for the filter wheels to be left at the end of the night.

SpNote.title: End of Night Echelle Emissivity
SpNote.note:
Measures the telescope emissivity. The procedure is as follows:
Ask the TSS to point at a patch of sky at zenith (not tracking or guiding).
Run this observation. - take the flat - take the sky frame
At the break after the sky frame, ask the TSS to close the mirror covers and dome.
- press continue, to take the dome frame
Finally the sequence does a DARK, which is the best place to leave the filter wheels at the end of the night.
The sequence will pause at this point so you can point at the dome.
SpNote.title: Now point at the dome
UFTI
SpNote.note:
Five sequences are given below. The first, "Pol jitter then angle" is the most efficient, since three images are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved. This uses the recipe POL_JITTER.
The second sequence, "Pol angle then jitter", reverses the order in which the telescope and waveplate are moved. This time images at the 4 waveplate positions are obtained BEFORE the telescope is jittered. This involves more waveplate moves (and so is less efficient) though it does follow the "Golden Rule of Polarimetry" more closely. This uses the recipe POL_ANGLE_JITTER.
The third sequence is used with extended sources (i.e. when blank sky cannot be extracted from the lower half of the array). The telescope is nodded between object and sky. 8 frames, consisting of an obj-sky pair at each of the 4 waveplate positions makes one cycle. Data from each cycle are combined by the recipe POL_EXTENDED.
NOTE: All recipes require that separate flat-field observations be acquired before they are run (use the "make_skyflat for Pol" sequences). Two skyflat sequences are available; the second obtains a separate flat at each of the four waveplate angles.
A dark with the same integration time as the object frames is also needed; this is included in the MSBs but needs to have its time defaulted in the usual way.
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.

SpNote.title: READ THIS
SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. We incorporate a template standard sequence (which is made optional); simply edit in your standard star ID, resolve the name and then alter UFTI settings.

This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
This is present to enable flat fields to be obtained for more than one filter. It is set to one filter because the data-reduction recipe currently cannot handle multi-colour data. The remainder of the note will apply once the recipe is made colour generic.
If you wish to observe at more than one wavelength, add filters to the "UFTI" component below, changing exposure times as required.
SpNote.title: Iterate through filters

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Polarimetry observations of a compact or point source. The sequence obtains a number of jittered frames at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, 67.5 degrees).
Note - this sequence is the "inverse" of the "Pol angle then jitter" sequence since the jitter frames are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved.
Use with POL_JITTER. A separate flat must have been obtained, as well as a dark.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection
E-W jitter at each WP position.
SpNote.note: The three E-W jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.
Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.

SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_ANGLE_JITTER expects a frame at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees); these four frames are repeated at a number of East-West jitter positions. A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All four waveplate positions are observed before the telescope is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection
Jitter AFTER 4 WP positions
SpNote.note: Jitter telescope positions three times after each set of four waveplate-offset frames are acquired. Offsets are 20-arcsecond steps E-W. There is also a 1-arcsecond N-S offset to sample different rows.
Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.

The sequence nods between object and blank sky at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees).
N.B. A separate flat-field must have been obtained, as well as a Dark.

Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.

SpNote.note:
For Pol imaging of an extended object that overlaps into the lower half of the UFTI array (i.e. is more than 30-40 arcsec in size). When this is the case, the lower e- and o-beam regions of each image cannot be used for blank sky brightness estimates; thus, separate blank sky frames must be acquired.
The sequence maps a 3x3 frame target region area with 50 per cent overlap, and nods between object and blank sky at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees).
N.B. A separate flat-field must have been obtained, as well as a Dark.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.

SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection
Obj-Sky pair at each WP position.
SpNote.note:
Nod between object and blank sky for each of the four waveplate positions. Repeat this sequence at three slightly jittered positions.
This set is akin to the 3x3 extended observation with 50% overlaps on the target and a jitter on a sky region.
Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Five sequences are given below for each camera. The first, "Pol jitter then angle" is the most efficient, since three images are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved. This uses the recipe POL_JITTER.
The second sequence, "Pol angle then jitter", reverses the order in which the telescope and waveplate are moved. This time images at the 4 waveplate positions are obtained BEFORE the telescope is jittered. This involves more waveplate moves (and so is less efficient) though it does follow the "Golden Rule of Polarimetry" more closely. This uses the recipe POL_ANGLE_JITTER.
The third sequence is used with extended sources (i.e. when blank sky cannot be extracted from the lower half of the array). The telescope is nodded between object and sky. 8 frames, consisting of an obj-sky pair at each of the 4 waveplate positions makes one cycle. Data from each cycle are combined by the recipe POL_EXTENDED.
NOTE: All recipes require that separate flat-field observations be acquired before they are run (use the "make_skyflat for Pol" sequences). Two skyflat sequences are available; the second obtains a separate flat at each of the four waveplate angles. A dark with the same integration time as the object frames is also needed.
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.
SpNote.title: IRCAM

POL_EXTENDED expects to receive eight frames for at least three jitter positions. The eight comprise pairs of object and sky exposures at each of the four waveplate positions. After each block of eight images the telescope is slightly jittered on the extended source to correct for bad pixels, etc.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection
Obj-Sky pair at each WP position.
SpNote.note: Nod between object and blank sky for each of the four waveplate positions. Repeat this sequence at three slightly jittered positions.
Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.
SpNote.title: CGS4
READ THIS
SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. We incorporate a template standard sequence (which is made optional); simply edit in your standard star ID, resolve the name and then alter IRCAM settings.

Simply takes a flat field and an arc lamp frame.
Be sure the CGS4 config matches that of your standard and target.
Be sure to hit the default button in the flat and arc editors if you change the configuration.
SpNote.title: Flat and Arc

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at http://www.jach.hawaii.edu/JACpublic/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/handbook.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your arcs and flats as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range -7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note:
You should select "prism" in the 'polariser' box. Note that with the prism, the slit is aligned to the prism rather than the array, so you will see sloping sky lines etc. in the data. The 2-pixel slit might be better aligned in terms of getting both the o- and e- polarimetry beams through the slit.
Best efforts are make to align all the slits, though obvioulsy it's more difficult to align the narrow (1 pixel) slit.
SpNote.title: cgs4+irpol

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data-reduction recipe for speed. (This is a good idea if your exposure time short.)
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the set of polarimetry frames in order to obtain the desired signal-to-noise on your target, use the repeat component below to specify how many times you want to repeat the sequence.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one cycle

SpNote.note: this nods 30 rows along the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This sequence interleaves irpol waveplate rotations and slit nodding.
The whole sequence looks like this:
Waveplate 0 degrees object sky waveplate 45 degrees sky object waveplate 22.5 degrees object sky waveplate 67.5 degrees sky object
SpNote.title: irpol info

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note: These are *not* MSBs; they are straightforward Observations. Some appear in the MSBs defined here, others (e.g. the make_skyflat for each WP angle) may be used as replacements.
SpNote.title: Utility sequences

SpObs.title: make_skyflat for each WP angle for Pol (UFTI)

SpNote.title: Usage
SpNote.note:
Construct separate flat fields for each of the four waveplate angles. Any number of sky frames can be combined into each flat; the recipe SKY_FLAT_POL_ANGLE should be used.
N.B. All current polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field.

Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
This recipe creates a flat field for each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). It requires frames consisting of at least three positions on the sky for each waveplate position, so that each group can be median averaged to form the flat.
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first.
If you do not need flats at each waveplate angle, select the observation "make_skyflat for Pol".
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
This is present to enable flat fields to be obtained for more than one filter. It is set to one filter because the data-reduction recipe currently cannot handle multi-colour data. The remainder of the note will apply once the recipe is made colour generic.
If you wish to observe at more than one wavelength, add filters to the "UFTI" component below, changing exposure times as required.
SpNote.title: Iterate through filters

SpNote.note:
This uses a 5-point cross-shape jitter at 60-arcsecond steps.
Guiding may be switched off at the telescope.
SpNote.title: 5pt on sky per WP angle

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero
Usage
SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).

Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
This is present to enable flat fields to be obtained for more than one filter. It is set to one filter because the data-reduction recipe currently cannot handle multi-colour data. The remainder of the note will apply once the recipe is made colour generic.
If you wish to observe at more than one wavelength, add filters to the "UFTI" component below, changing exposure times as required.
SpNote.title: Iterate through filters

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

READ THIS
SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UFTI Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

This sequence performs a nod-jitter; adjacent frames are subtracted to produce frames containing positive and negative images of the target. This works well in the thermal where the background varies rapidly.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The IRCAM component below uses the L' filter. To change it move the highlight to the "IRCAM3 component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The IRCAM3 component below uses a 0.2-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to IRCAM3 below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and a recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note:
The data-reduction recipe specified below uses the most-complete algorithm, save not masking to make the flat.
If you require aperture photometry of the positive and negative images too, select NOD_SELF_FLAT_NO_MASK_APHOT.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the dark exposure time in the IRCAM3 configuration above remember to change it here too.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure time matches that in your IRCAM3 setting above.
SpNote.title: set dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the quadrant jitter pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one 5-point jitter

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
Remember that changing the number of offsets will break the reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

Use the reset-to-default button to set the exposure time to match your object exposure time above.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time

SpNote.note: To repeat the quadrant pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one quadrant jitter

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
Quadrant jitters move the source into each quadrant of the array. The flat field is generated for each quadrant by using the data from the frames for which the source was not in that quadrant. This works well for small extended sources.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: For convenience this final offset ensures the telescope moves back to 0,0 after all the observations have completed.
SpNote.title: final offset
READ THIS
SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UFTI Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

This sequence is an example of how to do generic n-colour photometry efficiently in a single observation.
Although this is for JHK, you can change the filters to do any set.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Set a default IRCAM3 setup to start from here.
SpNote.title: IRCAM set up

SpNote.note:
The data-reduction recipe specified below uses the most complete data-reduction recipe.
This recipe does self flat reduction for each colour. If you do each colour more than once then the data will be co-added for each.
Separate reduced files are generated for each colour.
The algorithm is identical to JITTER_SELF_FLAT.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the dark exposure time in the IRCAM3 configuration above remember to change it here too.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Three darks are done here - one for each filter that will follow. Set the exposure times and co-adds to match those which you will do on the source in each band.
SpNote.title: set dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the 5-point jitter pattern more than once for each filter on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one 5-point jitter

SpNote.note: The IRCAM3 iteration component below changes the filter, starting with J. No exposure time is entered for J because it is already set in the general IRCAM3 setup above. The filter and exposure time are then changed for H and then again for K.
SpNote.title: IRCAM filter iteration

SpNote.note: If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset
READ THIS
SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UFTI Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

Makes a sky subtracted image. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 60 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guiding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un-guided".
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The IRCAM3 component below uses the L' filter. To change it move the highlight to the "IRCAM3 component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The IRCAM3 component below uses a 0.2-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "IRCAM3" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and a recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note:
CHOP_SKY_JITTER is suitable for extended sources that fill almost the whole array (so that sky frames or a flat field cannot be obtained from the on-source images). A median flat is constructed from ten "sky" observations, that are obtained after each object frame.
Recipe assumes that observations begin and end on sky.
N.B. A matching dark exposure also required.
If your observations are short, you may wish to substitute CHOP_SKY_JITTER_BASIC, which uses a no-frills algorithm.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UFTI configuration then remember to change it for the dark too.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset to defaults button to set the dark exposure time equal to the value from the component above.
SpNote.title: change exposure time here too

SpNote.note: To repeat the 9-point jitter pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one 9-point jitters

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region, which is defaulted to approximately 1 arcminute east of the target.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset ensures the telescope moves back to 0,0 after all the observations are completed.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UFTI Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The IRCAM3 component below uses the nbM filter. To change it move the highlight to the "IRCAM3 component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The IRCAM3 component below uses a 0.5-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "IRCAM3" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and the recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe used assumes that a flat field has already been created. It will not work unless you have done this. Use the observation "make sky flats" to do this.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the IRCAM3 exposure time in the component above then change the dark exposure time below to match it.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one

SpNote.note:
The first offset is to "sky"/"off the array".
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
Changing the total number of offsetswill break the data-reduction recipe.
Removing the offset to sky will break the recipe, as will changing the order.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset is not in the "repeat loop" because it just takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the observations have been taken, for convenience.

Exec for making a map of a source up to 30 arcseconds across. Images are taken in strips with semi-random ordering of positions in the strip and of the strip to minimise systematic errors due to sky fluctuations. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 45 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un-guided".
It starts with sky then the "middle" frame.
For larger targets see also "extended_5x5".
If speed is an issue, select the simplest form of the recipe, namely EXTENDED_3x3_BASIC.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The IRCAM component below uses the L' filter. To change it move the highlight to the "IRCAM3 component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The IRCAM component below uses a 0.2 second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "IRCAM3" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and a recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe assumes the order in which the images are taken; if you change this the recipe will not work.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time for the IRCAM3 configuration, then change it for the dark here too.
The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to set the exposure time for the dark equal to that for the source that you have set above.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region, which is defaulted to approximately 1 arcminute north-west of the target.
The target offsets are displaced to give 42% overlap. To obtain 50% overlap, change the target offsets (odd-numbered in the offset iterator below) to multiples of 10 arcseconds from the current 12 arcseconds.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset resets the telescope to 0,0 after all data taking is completed.
SpNote.title: back to 0,0

Exec for making a map of a source up to ~1' across. Images are taken in strips with semi-random ordering of postions in the strip and of the strip to minimise systematic errors due to sky fluctuations. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 120 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un guided"
It starts with sky then the "middle" frame.
If speed is an issue, select the simplest form of the recipe, namely EXTENDED_5x5_BASIC.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The IRCAM component below uses the L' filter. To change it move the highlight to the "IRCAM3 component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The IRCAM component below uses a 0.2 second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "IRCAM3" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and a recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe assumes the order in which the images are taken; if you change this the recipe will not work.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time for the UFTI configuration, then change it for the dark here too.
the data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to set the exposure time for the dark equal to that for the source that you have set above.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region, which is defaulted to approximately 3 arcminutes north-west of the target. The offsets are in groups of five as this is what the recipe uses to make flats for each row. The groups are slightly displaced from one another.
The target offsets are displaced to give 30% overlap. For 50% overlap, set the target offsets (odd-numbered in the offset iterator below) to to multiples of 10 and 20 arcseconds instead of 15 and 30 arcseconds.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset resets the telescope to 0,0 after all data taking is completed.
SpNote.title: back to 0,0

SpNote.note: these are observations, not MSBs. Array tests are available from the QT menu and do not need to be included. sky flats should be included in your msbs as needed (e.g. for bright standard stars or targets).
SpNote.title: utility sequences
Usage
SpNote.note:
To test array performance.
Recommended that this be run at the start of every IRCAM night.

3 x 1-second stare darks, so first can be thrown away
then 2 x 1-second ndstare darks
then a 60-second and a 10-second dark to calculate the dark current.
SpNote.title: darks
Usage
SpNote.note:
Use this observation to make some observations of blank sky which can be processed to generate flat fields. These are relevant if you are observing sources where the exposure time is too short to generate a flat field from the object jitter pattern.
The reduction recipe makes a flat that other reduction recipes can use.

Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The IRCAM3 component below uses the K filter. To change it move the highlight to the "IRCAM3 component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The IRCAM3 component below uses a 15-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "IRCAM3" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and a recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: This recipe generates a flat field that can be used by other data-reduction recipes. It masks residual stars to reduce artifacts and biases in the flat. If you do not want masking select recipe SKY_FLAT for object observation in the DRRecipe component below.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
Change the dark exposure time in the item below if you changed it in the IRCAM3 configuration.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure time matches that in your object.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset ensures that the telescope goes back to 0,0 after the last observation.
SpNote.title: last offset
FP sequences
SpNote.note:
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.

This sequence steps through FPZ settings (the plate separation) at four different setting of FPY (FPX fixed). The FPX and FPY values must be set accordingly before each FPZ-scan. Analyse the resulting sequence of frames with the shell script "alignfp". From the peak counts in the four plots, establish the best FPY value.
This alignment procedure should be done on the afternoon before your first night of observations (contact your support scientist!).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the S(1) filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
Short integration times are usually sufficient for FP alignment on the lamp.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: At present, only the QUICK_LOOK recipe is available for alignment purposes.
SpNote.title: DR recipe selection

SpNote.note:
This sequence steps through FPZ settings (the plate separation) at four different setting of FPX (FPY fixed). The FPX and FPY values must be set accordingly before each FPZ-scan. Analyse the resulting sequence of frames with the shell script "alignfp". From the peak counts in the four plots, establish the best FPX value.
This alignment procedure should be done on the afternoon before your first night of observations (contact your support scientist!).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the S(1) filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
Short integration times are usually sufficient for FP alignment on the lamp.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: At present, only the QUICK_LOOK recipe is available for alignment purposes.
SpNote.title: DR recipe selection

SpNote.note:
This sequence steps through only FPZ. 14 Exposures (+ a dark) are obtained.
The best values of FPX and FPY established for the period of your observing run should be entered into the FP iterator below.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the S(1) filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
Short integration times are usually sufficient for FP alignment with the lamp.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: At present, only the QUICK_LOOK recipe is available for alignment purposes.
SpNote.title: DR recipe selection

SpNote.note: Change the values of FPX and FPY in the "FP" iterator below. The second iterator will then step through FPZ to establish the FPZ value for peak transmission of the arc-lamp line.
SpNote.title: Set FPX, FPY below!

SpNote.note:
The sequence of FPZ values in the iterator below may not be appropriate for the CS100 settings on the instrument and the temperature in the dome. If you do NOT see a peak when you apply the shell script "alignfp" to your data, change the range of FPZ settings below.
You may also wish to repeat the scan with a few extra FPZ settings added to the iterator near the peak of the profile (for a more accurate measure of the FPZ value at peak flux). Use the "Add" button and enter the FPZ values in the box top-left in the FP iterator.
SpNote.title: Check sequence of FPZ settings

SpNote.note: Take a quick-look frame at a specific FPX, FPY, FPZ setting. Useful for checking the alignment of the lamp with the FP.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the S(1) filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
Short integration times are usually sufficient for FP alignment with the lamp.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: At present, only the QUICK_LOOK recipe is available for alignment purposes.
SpNote.title: DR recipe selection

SpNote.note: Change the values of FPX and FPY in the "FP" iterator below. The second iterator will then step through FPZ to establish the FPZ value for peak transmission of the arc-lamp line.
SpNote.title: Set FPX, FPY, and FPZ below!

SpObs.title: Flux standard for FP; 5pt jitter: Bright Point Source

SpNote.note:
5-point jitter offsets on a bright point source; a mosaic is obtained at each of three FPZ settings (on-line, off-line-blue, off-line-red).
THE FP VALUES MUST BE SET TO YOUR SPECIFIC VALUES!
It is assumed that the background signal through the FP is insufficient to construct a good "self flat". This sequence therefore requires a pre-observed flat field (use "make_skyflat for FP").
Use UFTI full array - thus, minimum exposure time is 4 seconds.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the K filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The UFTI component below uses a 5-second exposure time. To change it move the highlight to "UFTI" below and change the exposure time - either enter the value you want to use, or enter the magnitude range of your target and the recommended exposure time will be automatically entered.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note:
If you want to do aperture photometry change the Recipe to BRIGHT_POINT_SOURCE_APHOT.
NOTE: A separate flat must have been acquired and filed in the same filter (use "make_skyflats"); the recipe also requires a dark with the same integration time.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
After calibrating the FP in the afternoon, you should have calculated values for FPX and FPY which will set the plates parallel.
Enter these new values into the "FP" component below. FPZ will be over-written by the FP iterator below.
SpNote.title: FPX and FPY settings

SpNote.note: You MUST edit the FPZ settings in the FP iterator below. Set these to the on-line, off-line (blue) and off-line (red) FPZ values you will use on your target.
SpNote.title: FPZ settings

SpNote.note:
The 5 jitter positions on sky are nested within the FPZ iterator. Thus, one 5-point mosaic will be produced per FPZ setting.
Small offsets are used because of the phase shift across the FP field-of-view.
SpNote.title: 5 Jitter positions

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note:
This sequence makes a sky flat from four frames observed at the on-line and off-line FPZ settings.
Note - 500sec integration needed to get a few hundred counts on the array.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target. (Use the "Target List - position editor" to check for bright stars).
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the S(1) filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The UFTI component below uses a 120-second exposure time, which is necessary to get background limited when the FP is in the beam. To change it move the highlight to "UFTI" below and change the exposure time.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe, SKY_FLAT_FP, expects a block of dithered blank-sky frames. An equal number of frames on-line FPZ (x2), off-line (blue) FPZ and off-line (red) FPZ is recommended.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
After calibrating the FP in the afternoon, you should have calculated values for FPX and FPY which will set the plates parallel.
Enter these new values into the "FP" component below.
SpNote.title: FPX and FPY settings

SpNote.note: Return to 0,0 position on sky.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
This observation is designed to take FP images of an astronomical source, using the sequence:
On source - on line On sky - on line On sky - off line (red) On source - off line (red) On source - on line On sky - on line On sky - off line (blue) On source - off line (blue)
The data-reduction recipe will expect the data in this order and create on-line minus off-line images for both the source and the blank sky.
The offset to blank sky is set to 60,60 arcseconds.
N.B.: A separate flat field must be obtained prior to use of this sequence, otherwise the DR recipe will fail.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
The UFTI component below uses the S(1) filter. To change it move the highlight to the "UFTI component" below and select the filter you want to use.
The UFTI component below uses a 120-second exposure time, which is necessary to get background limited when the FP is in the beam. To change it move the highlight to "UFTI" below and change the exposure time.
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe is matched to the observing sequence, i.e. for online-offline/object-sky reduction.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
After calibrating the FP in the afternoon, you should have calculated values for FPX and FPY which will set the plates parallel.
Enter these new values into the "FP" component below (the value in FPZ doesn't matter; it'll be changed further down the sequence).
SpNote.title: FPX and FPY settings

SpObs.title: Flux standard for FP; 5pt jitter: Bright Point Source

SpNote.note:
5-point jitter offsets on a bright point source; a mosaic is obtained at each of three FPZ settings (on-line, off-line-blue, off-line-red).
THE FP VALUES MUST BE SET TO YOUR SPECIFIC VALUES!
It is assumed that the background signal through the FP is insufficient to construct a good "self flat". This sequence therefore requires a pre-observed flat field (use "make_skyflat for FP").
Use UFTI full array - thus, minimum exposure time is 4 seconds.

SpObs.title: Extended Source with Point Sources (2x3 scan)

SpNote.note: started with 0.08, 20 but moved to 0.1,10 on 20020423 (cloudy so shorter)

SpNote.title: emissivity check
SpNote.note:
This end of night observation does an emissivity check by measuring the sky and the dome flux in the thermal IR.
Before starting the sequence, move the telescope to zenith and make sure you are pointing at blank sky. Run the sequence and take the initial flatfield and sky observation (note: there is a break before the first flat - hit "continue" when this point is reached). The sequence then hits another break before taking the next observation. At this point, please close the dome and the mirror covers. When both are closed, hit "continue" and let the sequence run to the next break.
At the final break, you can run down the sequence console and OM, there is no need to take data on the final flat. It is there so that the Michelle window cover gets closed. Once you've reached the final break point, the window will have been closed by the "set object" command.

SpNote.title: What is this?
SpNote.note:
This is a sequence for doing Michelle peakup without using movie. It scans a distance of 4 arcsecs across the slit in steps of 0.5 arcsecs.
In order to use this sequence, you should make sure that the slit position angle, slit width, wavelength and grating are all changed to match the settings of your own observations. You will also need to keep the target component in the sequence as this will turn on chopping for you.
Sampling, which is set to 1x1 in this sequence, and the observation time, which is set to 10 seconds, need not be altered. These have been changed from the default Michelle settings in order to speed up peakup.

SpNote.title: What is this?
SpNote.note:
This is a sequence for doing Michelle peakup without using movie. It scans a distance of 4 arcsecs across the slit in steps of 0.5 arcsecs, and also performs an offset observation, along the slit, for sky subtraction purposes.
In order to use this sequence, you should make sure that the slit position angle, slit width, wavelength and order are all changed to match the settings of your own observations.
Sampling, which is set to 1x1 in this sequence, and the observation time, which is set to 20 seconds, need not be altered.
